Women are currently under-represented in many of these trades and areas. For example, they make up only two per cent of electricians and one per cent of mechanics and carpenters. We see similar results across the range of more male dominated apprenticeships. Women make up only five per cent of electrical and mechanic apprentices and two per cent of carpenter apprentices. This is way too low.

We can ensure women's participation in the trades through quality prevocational and vocational education, the active recruitment of women and girls, and good support in group training and employment environments. This takes planning and execution. It won't happen without targets and without tangible actions to achieve those targets. I know this because I spent a few years of my life in the Newcastle region trying to increase the share of young women training in non-traditional occupations. It's hard work but it pays off in pay packets for those young women and in lifetime careers in useful occupations like electrical apprenticeships, plumbing and so on.

In the process of our inquiry, at one of our meetings here in Canberra, we heard from the National Electrical and Communications Association, NECA. They train about one in four electrical apprentices in Australia through group training programs. In their ACT branch they've reached a record 15 per cent of apprentices who are women. They've achieved this through targeted action and quality pre-employment programs, and they've got good support for apprentices. Labor announced in the budget a $95.6 million investment, over nine years, to train 10,000 new apprentices in the new energy jobs of the future. In my view, Labor needs to ensure that at least 15 per cent, and hopefully more, of these apprenticeships go to women. NECA have shown that, with targeted actions, it's possible to achieve it, and it will change women's lives.

This issue is particularly important in South Australia, where we've got really severe shortages—for example, of electricians—at the moment. Employers are desperately fighting for workers, and we need to help them train the workforce of the future. It's critical that we consider gender equity in our economic transition, or women will be left behind. As an agency set up to provide advice on our future labour market, JSA is well placed to perform this role.

In sum, and in conclusion, the Greens support this bill, as revised following our very productive discussions with Labor. At the jobs summit, stakeholders, including unions, business, women and community organisations, were very clear that more needs to be done. The Greens will continue to push to ensure that gender equality and social equity outcomes are at the centre of any further jobs, skills and workplace legislation. With Senator Faruqi, I look forward to working with the Labor government on a strong, equitable, public vocational training system advised by JSA.

Senator ROBERTS (Queensland) (20:36): As a servant to the people of Queensland and Australia, I speak to the Jobs and Skills Australia Bill 2022 and the Job and Skills Australia (National Skills Commissioner Repeal) Bill 2022. These bills repeal the National Skills Commissioner Act, replace the commissioner's position with Jobs and Skills Australia as a new statutory body within the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations, and set out the initial functions of Jobs and Skills Australia.

The interim Jobs and Skills Australia Director will commence urgent work now and lead the agency through its initial set-up. The agency's final duties and responsibilities and related matters will then come back to parliament in legislation for our approval or, presumably, modification. It's expected that the agency will advise the government and industry on research and provide data analysis to inform policies that boost workforce participation, as well as better matching training and education with industry needs. This seems fair, and One Nation will be supporting the bills. I must, though, say this: the role of this agency can be described as to assist in the central planning of the Australian economy. One Nation would be objecting more strongly to these bills if the agency did not already exist in another name, the National Skills Commission. The not-conservative Morrison government, in 2020, introduced the original National Skills Commissioner for central planning. With central planning having already been created in the labour and education markets, these bills are a genuine attempt to make the planning better.

History around the world proves that industry has the resources and a vested interest in planning its own needs in respect of the skill level, education, training, apprenticeship mix and suchlike involved in running a business. History proves beyond any doubt, repeatedly, that individual businesses are best placed to do this planning for themselves, at times, possibly, with the assistance of industry professional associations and unions. Instead, with these bills, the taxpayer bears the cost of forward planning, apparently with no cost recovery—although, as the final form of the agency is not yet determined, I hope that a cost recovery aspect will be put in place. Otherwise, the concept of this and the previous iteration—the socialisation of costs and the privatisation of profits—is a concept One Nation objects to. We hope the Albanese Labor government is not getting up to that caper. We had enough of that under the Liberal-National government of Mr Morrison and Mr Joyce.

Governments lack responsibility for individual business outcomes. That is clear. That means governments lack accountability. That is the fundamental reason that central planning fails—every time it's tried it fails. One Nation looks forward to a day when big business does its own planning, skills and training, like they used to before they got lazy and the government took it over.

While we do not support government doing central planning of these basic business responsibilities, we see this bill as a step in the right direction away from central planning and back to where the responsibility should be. We are one community, we are one nation, and the right to profit comes with an obligation for businesses to pull their own weight.

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:40): I thank all members for their contributions to this debate. There has never been a greater need for an organisation like Jobs and Skills Australia. Australia is experiencing an acute skills shortage, and tightening labour market conditions have exacerbated the existing workforce pressures all across the country. Businesses are reporting significant challenges finding suitably skilled staff to fill vacancies, and many workers do not have skills that align with the current needs of industry and employers. There is a genuine and growing need for a workforce with relevant and high-quality skills in traditional sectors like construction and the care workforce and in emerging sectors such as clean energy and digital technology.

We need to act now, and the initial establishment of Jobs and Skills Australia will enable the essential work that is needed to find solutions to these skills and workforce challenges to start immediately. We also need to work in partnership with industry, unions, the education and training sector and students to ensure that we get this right. We will continue to engage widely prior to introducing further legislation to establish the permanent Jobs and Skills Australia. This approach will ensure that Jobs and Skills Australia is designed in a way that considers the needs of all key stakeholders in our workforce and skills system. These are shared challenges and all levels of government, industry, business, employers, unions and education providers must work together if we are to unlock the full potential of Australia's workforce and ensure Australians have the skills and training needed for the jobs of today and the future.
Once again, I thank everyone for their engagement and support and the constructive nature of the proposed amendments to these bills.
Question agreed to.
Bills read a second time.
In Committee
Bills—by leave—taken together and as a whole.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Senator Fawcett ) (20:42): The question is that the bills stand as printed.

Se
nator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:43): Minister, when I go to the explanatory memorandum to the bill, it notes that the bill will establish a new statutory body within the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations and set out the initial functions of Jobs and Skills Australia It also notes that the permanent model for Jobs and Skills Australia is yet to be confirmed. When will the permanent model be confirmed?

Se
nator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:43): Consultation is underway and we expect the legislation to be released early next year.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:43): When did this consultation commence? What does this consultation involve? In particular, who are you consulting with?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:44): The consultation started once the legislation committee released its report. It will be ongoing in the lead-up to the legislation being released. The consultation has been with all the sectors involved, including unions and industry.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:44): Could you take me through which unions you have consulted with?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:44): There's been consultation with the peak body—the ACTU—and also the ETU and the education union.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:44): When does the position of the National Skills Commissioner formally come to an end?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:45): That will be a week after royal assent.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:45): Do you mean royal assent of this particular bill that we currently have before us?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:45): It would be the repeal bill that we're also debating.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:45): In relation to the interim head, or director, of Jobs and Skills Australia, what process is the government going to put in place in terms of the appointment?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:45): It would be appropriate Remuneration Tribunal arrangements.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:45): Could you take us through what the appropriate Remuneration Tribunal arrangements are? In particular, will you be going to market in relation to this appointment? Will it be appointed by the cabinet or directly by the Prime Minister? What qualifications will you require this person to have?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:46): It will initially be an interim appointment. The person will obviously be very well qualified, and we will seek to ensure that.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:46): With all due respect, when you say, 'the person will be very well qualified', I think in your summing-up speech you said that there has never been a greater need or time for Jobs and Skills Australia. So, with all due respect, I would certainly hope that they are going to be appropriately qualified. Given that—to summarise what you said—there has never been a greater need for Jobs and Skills Australia, I assume the government has given some form of thought to the qualifications that would be required for the interim Jobs and Skills Australia director. Again, I ask you: What is an appropriately qualified person? What are the qualifications they will have?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:47): Obviously we would seek someone who has expertise in the training sector and experience in the education sector. It would be someone who we think would be appropriate for such a position.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:47): Which unions have you discussed the appointment of the interim Jobs and Skills Australia director with?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:47): We have not mentioned names to any unions that we've met with.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:47): Which unions have you met with? What discussions have you had? Have the unions provided you with any names?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:48): All stakeholders that we've met with have put forward suggestions that they think would be appropriate.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:48): Again, without verballing you, I'll get you to confirm that that includes that unions that have put forward names that they believe would be appropriate. What names have they put forward? What are the qualifications that these people have?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:48): As I said, all stakeholders that we've met with, including unions, have put forward suggestions of who they think would be appropriate.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:48): I'm going to work on the basis that that wasn't the name of a person. Again, I ask you—and if you're not going to say, just say, 'I'm not going to say.' What names have the unions put forward to you? What qualifications do these people have?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:48): I'm not going to reveal names that people have suggested, but I can confirm that I am very confident the government will ensure there's an appropriate appointment made to this position.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:49): Given the comments that Mr Albanese has made in relation to appointments made, and the way in which those comments say certain appointments were made by the former government, can the minister guarantee that this position will be advertised, it'll go to market and there will be, to quote Mr Albanese, 'a proper selection process'? It will not be a direct appointment?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:49): Because it's an interim appointment, my understanding is, it doesn't need to go through that process for an interim spot.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:49): I understand the answer that you provided. You said you understand it does not need to. With all due respect though, the Prime Minister has made certain statements in relation to the way appointments are made. Can you guarantee that even though it is an interim appointment the Prime Minister will be true to his word? It won't be a direct appointment by the Prime Minister or by the cabinet or by the minister; it will be one that is advertised, goes to market and a selection process is undertaken?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:50): What I can confirm is in the final form—so not for the interim position but when this is finalised—it will go through that process.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:50): Is the minister able to confirm if Mr Boyton will be the interim director?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:50): He won't be. But my understanding is that the government have had very considered discussions with that gentleman.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:51): Did the government consult the National Skills Commissioner or were the staff at the commission consulted as part of establishing Jobs and Skills Australia?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:51): The minister has had very detailed conversations with Mr Boyton.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:51): In relation to the very detailed conversations with Mr Boyton that you refer to, when did these conversations occur? You said they were very detailed conversations with a 's', so I assume that means that there was more than one? When did these conversations occur, and, in particular, when did the first conversation occur and in what format did this conversation, or these conversations, take place?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:52): These conversations started directly after the election. My understanding is that they were in person.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:52): Has the government made a decision in relation to who will be the interim Jobs and Skills Australia director?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:52): No formal decision has been made.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:52): Put aside a formal decision, has an informal decision been made in relation to who the interim director of Jobs and Skills Australia will be?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:52): Multiple candidates are being considered.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:52): When you say multiple candidates, how many candidates?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:53): After an initial look and the net being cast quite wide, they have whittled that down now to a number of potentials that due diligence has been done on.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:53): When you say a number of potentials, how many are we actually referring to?

Senator
CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:53): There are two leading candidates that due diligence has been done on.
Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:53): When will the government announce the interim director of Jobs and Skills Australia?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:54): The intention would be to do it as soon as possible. But it is possible that an arrangement could be made with the existing staff.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:54): As soon as possible—I might ask you if you could try and narrow that down to an actual time frame. When you say it is possible that existing arrangements could be made—I don't understand—what does it actually mean?

Senator CHISHOLM
( Queensland —Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) ( 20:54 ): I can't give a time line on a formal process. I'll attempt to be a bit more articulate: someone could be appointed from the existing staff, because they're all departmental staff in an acting capacity.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:54): Why is Jobs and Skills Australia a function or agency of the department, unlike the National Skills Commission, which is an independent agency?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:55): My understanding is that the agency is part of the department.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:55): I'll put the question again, in case it was just misunderstood. You're establishing a new statutory body within the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations. Why did you make this decision when, looking at the National Skills Commission, it is an independent agency? What was the rationale for this decision?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:56): I don't agree that it is an independent agency.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:56): Could I take you to the explanatory memorandum again, which notes, 'Jobs and Skills Australia will give effect to the government's commitments to tripartism.' In relation to the words 'give effect to the government's commitments to tripartism', what does that actually mean?

Senator CHISHOLM
( Queensland —Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Busi ness in the Senate) ( 20:56 ): That means that we engage with unions, employers and state governments.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:56): In terms of giving effect to the government's commitments to tripartism, that will be with unions, employers and state governments?
Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:57): Yes.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:57): What role does the government envisage unions will therefore play or have as part of the new organisation, Jobs and Skills Australia?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:57): There's a legislative requirement that government consult with the stakeholders I mentioned previously. Obviously, if you have been paying attention to the way the Albanese government is operating, you would have seen we are always seeking to engage and talk with relevant stakeholders. The best evidence of that is the skills summit that we had. Having industry and workers represented was a key part, I think, of the success of that, and that's something that we think is important in this area as well.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:58): Perhaps I need to be a little more explicit. Will there be a formal role for unions in relation to Jobs and Skills Australia?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (20:58): It's in the legislation that they're required to be consulted.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (20:58): I'll go to the National Skills Commissioner Act 2020. When you look at the functions of the National Skills Commissioner, they include:
(1) The functions of the Commissioner are:
(a) to provide advice to the Minister or to the Secretary in relation to the following:
(i) Australia's current, emerging and future workforce skills needs;
(ii) the development of efficient prices for VET courses;
(iii) the public and private return on government investment in VET qualifications;
(iv) the performance of Australia's system for providing VET;
(v) issues affecting the state of the Australian and international labour markets;
(vi) opportunities to improve access, skills development and choice for regional, rural and remote Australia in relation to VET; and
(b) to inform the public about the matters mentioned in paragraph (a); and
(c) to collect, analyse, share and publish data and other information about the matters mentioned in paragraph (a) to inform policy development and program delivery …
So that's the current act that's in place.

When you then go to the explanatory memorandum in relation to this bill, it notes that the functions of Jobs and Skills Australia are to include providing advice to the minister or the secretary in relation to Australia's current, emerging and future skills and training needs and priorities, including in relation to: apprenticeships and the adequacy of the Australian system in providing vocational education and training, including training outcomes; the undertaking of research and analysis on the resourcing and funding requirements for registered training organisations to deliver accessible quality VET courses; the undertaking of workforce forecasting; access to workforce skills requirements and the undertaking of cross-industry workforce analysis; and the collection, analysis, sharing and publication of data and other information about these matters.
So my question to you is: what is the substantial difference between the current and the proposed in relation to these two functions?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (21:00): There are two substantial areas that I would focus on. The first is in workforce planning, and a few of the contributions touched on it. At the risk of engaging Senator Roberts's ire, I think that was something he talked about, but maybe not in a good way. But Jobs and Skills Australia will undertake a workforce-planning function that I don't think was represented in the previous model. This will support a nationally consistent picture of Australia's workforce needs and the factors contributing to workforce demand and supply imbalances across the labour market. If I had to give an example of where that could most apply and where it would be most useful in our current challenges, it would probably be around that workforce we need for the renewable energy future that we want to build as a government. Obviously that's an ambitious agenda. I know, for instance, that labour has had to be imported for the New South Wales-South Australia interconnector that is being built. That's the first project of many that we need to do if we are to connect these renewables to the grid. So I think that's a really good example of where workforce planning can be effective.

The other way this new structure will be more effective is that it will be different to the previous model and will therefore support better outcomes because it has that strong collaboration with those tripartite partners, as we talked about before.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:02): The budget papers state, in relation to the financial impact statement, that Jobs and Skills Australia will be funded from savings realised by abolishing the role of the National Skills Commissioner. Can you confirm whether more funding will be appropriated to Jobs and Skills Australia after it is legislated?

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (21:03): Everything was in the budget, but the additional was the $1.9 million through the Clean Energy Capacity Study. So that will be in addition.

Senator CASH (Western Australia—Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) (21:03): by leave—In respect of the Jobs and Skills Australia Bill 2022, I move opposition amendments (1) to (4) on sheet 1664 together:
(1) Clause 9, page 4 (line 7), before "Jobs and Skills Australia has the following functions", insert "(1)".
(2) Clause 9, page 5 (after line 8), at the end of the clause, add:

(2) Jobs and Skills Australia must, before the end of each calendar year beginning on or after 1 January 2023, prepare and give to the Minister a report on Australia's current, emerging and future skills and training needs and priorities (including in relation to apprenticeships) during the calendar year.
(3) The Minister must table the report in each House of the Parliament:
(a) within the period of 14 calendar days after receiving the report; or
(b) if no sitting day of the relevant House occurs within that period—on the next sitting day of that House after the end of that period.
(4) Jobs and Skills Australia must, within 14 calendar days after giving the report to the Minister, publish the report:
(a) on the Department's website; or
(b) if the rules specify another manner in which the report is to be published—in that manner.
(3) Clause 27, page 12 (after line 13), after subclause (2), insert:
(2A) A direction under subsection (1) must be in writing.
(2B) The Minister must table a copy of each direction given under subsection (1) in each House of the Parliament as soon as practicable after giving the direction.
(4) Clause 27, page 12 (line 16), omit ", if in writing,".

I will speak briefly to these amendments; I know the hour is drawing to a close. I thank the Senate for the support that is given to the amendments. In relation to the function of Jobs and Skills Australia, currently the National Skills Commission is required to provide an annual report to the minister that reflects Australia's current, emerging and future workforce skills needs during the calendar year. This is tabled to parliament. This report provides important information about the state of the Australian economy and provides accountability for government priorities against that context.

In the bill we have before us, the government has removed the formal requirement for the Jobs and Skills Australia director to report to parliament at all. We say that this is a decrease in the transparency of Jobs and Skills Australia relative to the existing National Skills Commissioner, and we believe that parliamentary accountability should be a feature of Jobs and Skills Australia.

In relation to the ministerial directions, there are concerns in the training sector that the Albanese government has watered down accountability when it comes to the way in which the minister is able to direct the Jobs and Skills Australia director. Under the National Skills Commissioner Act 2020 the minister was able to give directions to the commissioner only by way of a legislative instrument. What we are seeing in this bill—again, I appreciate that the amendment will go through, so this will change—is Labor seeking to reduce this oversight in the explanatory memorandum, which notes it is not necessary for these directions to be given in writing.

Changes to the explanatory memorandum have removed the need for ministerial direction to the Jobs and Skills Australia director to be given in writing and provided to the parliament. We say that this is problematic and needs to be addressed. Certainly stakeholders have recommended that any ministerial direction to the Jobs and Skills Australia director given pursuant to the act must be given in writing, and we're of the opinion that it is vital that we introduce such accountability into this new agency. And, as I said, I do thank the chamber because I understand the amendments are being supported.

Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (21:06): Yes, we do intend to support the amendments, although I want to make a couple of comments. It was the government's intention to always improve transparency of Jobs and Skills Australia and our ways of working, including through the publication of an annual skills report. I would point out that, unlike our predecessors, we don't need that to be legislated into transparency because we are committed in our actions. Having said that, we are comfortable with supporting this amendment and we understand the nature of the contributions from Senator Cash.

The TEMPORARY CHAIR
( Se nator Pratt ): The question is that opposition amendments (1) to (4) on sheet 1664 be agreed to.
Question agreed to.

SHEET 1678

(c) employers, unions, training providers, universities and other industry stakeholders, and other persons or bodies with an interest in the labour market, workforce skills or workforce training needs.
SHEET 1680
(1) Clause 9, page 4 (after line 24), at the end of paragraph 9(a), add:
(vii) opportunities to remove barriers to achieving gender equality in the provision of training and in the labour market, and opportunities to improve gender equality outcomes;
Question agreed to.
Jobs and Skills Australia Bill 2022, as amended, agreed to; Jobs and Skills Australia (National Skills Commissioner Repeal) Bill 2022 agreed to.
Jobs and Skills Australia Bill 2022 reported with amendments; Jobs and Skills Australia (National Skills Commissioner Repeal) Bill 2022 reported without amendments; report adopted.
Third Reading
Senator CHISHOLM (Queensland—Assistant Minister for Education, Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Deputy Manager of Government Business in the Senate) (21:09): I move:
That these bills be now read a third time.
Question agreed to.
Bills read a third time.
